section.title: OmegaT highlights
section.para: OmegaT is a free multi platform Computer Aided Translation tool, with the following highlights:

listitem.para: Translation memory: OmegaT memorizes your translations in a translation memory. At the same time it can use memories from previous translations for reference. Translation memories can be very useful for a translation with a number of repetitions or reasonably similar segments of text. OmegaT uses translation memories to remember your previous translations and suggest to you the most probable translations for the text you are working on

The translation memories can be very useful when a document, that's been already translated, needs to be updated. Unchanged sentences will remain as translated, and updated sentences will be shown with an older version of the same sentence as the most probable translation. Modifications to the original document will thus be handled with greater ease. If you are using previously created translation memories, for example given to you by translation agency or your client, OmegaT will be able to use them as a reference memories.

OmegaT uses the standard TMX file format to store and access translation memories, which guarantees that you can exchange your translation material with other CAT applications, supporting this file format.

Terminology management:Terminology management is important for translation consistency. OmegaT uses glossaries that contain translations of single words or small phrases, a sort of simplified bilingual dictionary for a specific domain. OmegaT displays the translation of those words that happen to be present in the current segment for your reference.

Translation process: Imagine having to translate anything from a single file to a folder that contains subfolders with a number of files in a variety of formats. When you let OmegaT know that you need to translate those files it will look for the included files it supports according to the file filtering rules, recognize the textual parts in them, split the biggest text groups according to the segmentation rules and display the segments one by one so that you can proceed with the translation. OmegaT will memorize your translations and will propose you translation candidates for segments similar to those recorded in memory. Once you want to see how the files would look once translated, you can create the translated files open them in the appropriate application and see what your translation looks like.

section.title: Summary of chapters
section.para: This documentation should serve both as a learning help and as a reference guide. Here a short summary of chapters and its contents.

listitem.para: Â Start Using OmegaT in 5 Minutes! this chapter is intended as a Instant Start Guide for beginners and tyre kickers,showing the complete way from opening a new translation project to the finished translation.

Installing OmegaT and running it: this chapter will be useful when starting to use OmegaT. It contains the specific instructions on how to install OmegaT and run it for Windows, OS X, and Linux users.

The user interface,and Main Menu and Keyboard Short-cuts: these two chapters will be among often read, as they explain the user interface of OmegaT and the functions available via the main menu and the keyboard shortcuts. C

Project properties and OmegaT Files and Directories: a project in the context of OmegaT is the piece of work OmegaT as a CAT tool can work on. In this chapter the project properties, like the source and the target languages, are described. The latter chapter describes different subfolders and files in the translation project and their role, as well as other user and application files, connected with OmegaT.
Editing field behaviour: a short chapter, describing how the editing of the segment being translated can be set up.

Working with plain text and Working with formatted text: these two chapters explain some important points, as regards texts to be translated, like the encoding set used - in the case of plain text files - and the tag handling - in the case of formatted text.
Translation memories: explains the role of different subdirectories that contain translation memories and provides information on some other important aspects connected with translation memories.

Segmentation: translation memory tools work with textual units called segments. In OmegaT segments can ntatin be either based on paragraphs - rarely used option, retained mainly for historical reasons - or on a rule-based segmentation. A number of rules is already available, however, additional rules can be defined by the user, as described in this chapter.

Searches: and Regular expressions: Searches in OmegaT can be as simple as "list segments containing memory". Or they can be more involved, for instance, when proofreading the target text: "list segments with target text containing two or more consecutive spaces". In the second example the regular expression ^s^s+ will find and list the offending segments. Regular expressions are extensively used also segmentation rules.

Dictionaries, Glossaries, Machine translation and Spellchecker: OmegaT allows extensive use of dictionaries and glossaries. When online, different MT services, like Google Translate can be used. If spell checking is activated, the spelling mistakes are being recognized and can be corrected while translating the texts.
Miscellanea: contains different issues of interest, for instance how to avoid data loss and similar.
Appendices contain the following information
OmegaT on the web: information about on-line OmegaT sources
Languages: contains the ISO list of languages and language codes
Keyboard shortcuts: the list of shortcuts used in the editor
Keyword index: an extensive keyword index is provided to help the reader find the relevant information.
